results.headline: Little Lives Caught in a Troubled No Man’s Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In My Mother's Arms

results.summary_short: “In My Mother’s Arms” follows the happenings at a Baghdad shelter for 32 boys.

results.headline: One Woman’s Family, a String of Casualties in the War on Drugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The House I Live In

results.summary_short: In the documentary “The House I Live In,” Eugene Jarecki, inspired by his longtime black caretaker, investigates the country’s drug policy and its racial and class implications.

results.headline: An Everyman Who’s Not O.K.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's Such a Beautiful Day

results.summary_short: “It’s Such a Beautiful Day” is about an Everyman with complexities.

results.headline: Pitting Drug Regimens Against Prevention
results.display_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare

results.summary_short: “Escape Fire” argues that we can switch from a “disease management system” that relies on drugs to one that focuses on prevention over cure.

results.headline: Heathcliff and Cathy, With Lust and Mud

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wuthering Heights

results.summary_short: Andrea Arnold’s film adaptation of “Wuthering Heights” emphasizes mud, misery and savage, inarticulate feelings in an attempt to restore raw passion to the classic novel.

results.headline: Gory Discoveries in a Video Collection

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of V/H/S

results.summary_short: “V/H/S” continues the found-footage craze with five shorts emerging from a primary story about a hoard of videotapes discovered in a dead man’s house.

results.headline: The Saviors Themselves Are Damaged

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trade of Innocents

results.summary_short: Siem Reap, Cambodia, is the setting for “Trade of Innocents,” a drama about child trafficking.

results.headline: In a State of Sweaty Agitation in Steamy Florida

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Paperboy

results.summary_short: “The Paperboy,” a tangled and steamy drama directed by Lee Daniels, stars Nicole Kidman as a woman whose fiancé, played by John Cusack, is an alligator hunter on death row.

results.headline: Suburban Wasteland of Friends Adrift

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Oranges

results.summary_short: “The Oranges” is a dysfunctional-family comedy that backs away in terror from its potentially explosive subject.

results.headline: In Harm’s Way in Istanbul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taken 2

results.summary_short: The sequel to “Taken” finds relatives of sex traffickers seeking revenge against an ex-C.I.A. operative.

results.headline: When Life Seems Like One Long Rainstorm
results.display_title: Someday This Pain Will be Useful to You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Someday This Pain Will be Useful to You

results.summary_short: In “Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You,” based on a novel by Peter Cameron, a teenager explores his angst.

results.headline: With His Small, Sticky Fingers, a Hustler Tugs at Emotions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sister

results.summary_short: Using themes of rich and poor, “Sister” tells the story of a boy and his sister ingratiating themselves at a ski resort.

results.headline: It’s Aliiiive! And Wagging Its Tail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frankenweenie

results.summary_short: Tim Burton’s “Frankenweenie,” a 3-D stop-motion animated homage to classic horror movies, is both a quiet, quirky spoof and a loud and crazy action comedy.

results.headline: An Outsider Trying to Get Out of the Doldrums

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fat Kid Rules the World

results.summary_short: “Fat Kid Rules the World,” an adaptation of K. L. Going’s novel, brings to the screen the story of a teenager dealing with multiple issues, including being overweight.

results.headline: My Father the Juggernaut

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Atomic Age

results.summary_short: Gotham Chopra chronicles a year in the life of his globe-trotting father.

results.headline: Let the Carving Wars Begin!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Butter

results.summary_short: In “Butter” a form of sculpture turns political, and one contestant in a competition is determined to win.

results.headline: Romance Is a Dish That Sometimes Grows Cold

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Now, Forager

results.summary_short: “Now, Forager,” directed by Jason Cortlund and Julia Halperin, follows a couple who find food but miss out on happiness.

results.headline: Two Bulgarian Wastrels, Happiest on the Road

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Avé

results.summary_short: The Bulgarian buddy film “Avé” finds a man and a woman who are happiest when they are in flux.

results.headline: Following an Artist’s Footsteps in the Sand

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Double Steps

results.summary_short: “The Double Steps” from Isaki Lacuesta weaves a fable around an American-born artist who painted in the Sahara.

results.headline: Putting Philippine Justice on Trial

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Give Up Tomorrow

results.summary_short: “Give Up Tomorrow” details the doubts surrounding a late-1990s rape and murder case in the Philippines.
